<div style="text-align: center; font-size: 35px; font-weight: bold;">
  Plot with two segments using ggplot2
</div>

## Load libraries

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
library(cowplot)
```

## Generate sample data

```{r}
df <- data.frame(
  x = 1:20,
  # y has two ranges of data, one with the mean of 10, the other one with the mean of 100
  y = c(rnorm(10, mean = 10), rnorm(10, mean = 100))
)
```

## Create two plots (i.e. p1 and p2)

```{r}
p1 <- ggplot(df[1:10, ], aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_line() +
  labs(x = "X-axis", y = "") +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(
    plot.margin = margin(t = 0, l = 1, unit = "cm")    
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(8, 12, by = 1), limits = c(8, 12))

p2 <- ggplot(df[11:20, ], aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_line() +
  labs(title = "Plot with two segments", x = "", y = "") +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 15, face = "bold"),    
    plot.margin = margin(b = 0, l = 1, t = 0.5, unit = "cm"),
    panel.border = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_blank(),
    axis.line.x = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x = element_blank()
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(98, 103, by = 1), limits = c(98, 103))
```

## Use cowplot to merge the two plots of p1 and p2 vertically

```{r}
combined_plot <- plot_grid(p2, p1, ncol = 1, align = "v", rel_heights = c(1, 2), vjust = 0)

final_plot <- ggdraw(combined_plot) +
  draw_label(expression(paste("E (cm", H[2], "O/mL)")), x = 0.05, y = 0.5, angle = 90, hjust = 0.5, vjust = 0.5)

final_plot
```
